aboutSection.title: Who we are
aboutSection.description: The Seismic Risk Reduction Association (Re:Rise) is the community's response to the urgent need to reduce seismic vulnerability in Romania. Re:Rise acts as a bridge between those exposed to seismic risk and, on the other hand, the available technological, financial, administrative, and human resources.

contactSection.description: We’re used to talking about earthquakes with a seemingly innate fatalism. We quickly close the topic, either with a 'God forbid,' an aphorism about fate, or a detached joke. Maybe this is natural, considering it’s been 14 years since the last notable earthquake here, in October 2004, and the only one experienced by the younger generation. At a magnitude of 6.0, it was merely a test of reactions, with zero damages recorded.

projectsPage.title: What We Do at Re:Rise?
projectsPage.description: Re:Rise is an association that works to reduce seismic vulnerability in Romania by connecting those at risk with available resources. The organization implements five key solutions, including a Digital Equipment Registry for intervention forces, a Rapid Drone Mapping System for authorities, and the Rescuer's WiFi Mesh for communication between rescuers and victims.

firstProject.title: Bucharest After the Earthquake
firstProject.description: that calls for preparation and learning by illustrating both the footprint of vulnerable buildings (RS I, U1, U2, U3, RS II), as well as the approximate collapse area of these buildings and the road segments at risk of blockage due to rubble.
firstProject.firstListItem: What will the new map of post-seismic Bucharest look like? Which streets will be blocked by debris?
firstProject.secondListItem: How do we reach those trapped under debris / those in need as quickly as possible?
firstProject.thirdListItem: Which are the problematic zones and neighborhoods at risk of isolation from intervention teams?

description.unbolded1: By profession an engineer, but in essence a true polymath,
description.bolded1: Gheorghe Ursu was the first to publicly raise awareness about Bucharest’s seismic vulnerability.
description.unbolded2: Through a letter sent to Radio Free Europe, he denounced that, following the 1977 earthquake, repairs were prematurely halted by Ceaușescu's direct order,
description.bolded2: leaving the people of Bucharest exposed to future earthquakes.
description.unbolded3: For his act of truth-telling and his refusal to retract his statements, he was ultimately
description.bolded3: killed by the security forces on November 17, 1985.

thirdProject.title: The Criminal Order

description.firstSection: Four months after the March 1977 earthquake, Nicolae Ceaușescu called an urgent meeting in Bucharest. On July 4, about 300 people (engineers, architects, party leaders, and local administration officials) were gathered in a hall behind the Communist Central Committee, where Ceaușescu ordered them to halt all reinforcement work on buildings affected by the earthquake.
description.secondSection: In the capital alone, over 10,000 buildings were thus left vulnerable.
description.thirdSection: Re:Rise publishes for the first time the transcript of that meeting and evidence of this criminal order.
